statement.text: Pedal arch assessment evaluates the integrity of the dorsal and plantar arterial arches of the foot, determining runoff adequacy for tibial interventions and predicting wound healing potential in CLTI.
statement.formal: Dorsal arch: DP → lateral tarsal → arcuate artery; Plantar arch: PT → medial/lateral plantar → deep plantar; Complete vs incomplete arch affects runoff and healing

explanation.intuition: The pedal arteries form interconnected arches like a highway system for the foot - if one road is blocked, traffic can reroute through connecting loops. Complete arches allow collateral flow; incomplete arches leave areas vulnerable.
explanation.key_insight: Pedal arch patency is the ultimate determinant of revascularization success - a patent arch can compensate for single-vessel tibial disease.
explanation.technical_details: The pedal circulation consists of two interconnected arch systems: (1) The dorsal arch, formed by the dorsalis pedis artery giving the lateral tarsal and arcuate arteries, which supply the dorsal metatarsals; (2) The plantar arch, formed by the lateral plantar artery (from PT) connecting to the deep plantar artery (from DP). A complete pedal arch allows perfusion of all forefoot angiosomes from either AT/DP or PT. Arch assessment on angiography or duplex predicts runoff quality and healing potential.
common_misconceptions: If DP pulse is absent, pedal arch is occluded - FALSE, may have retrograde filling from PT
Complete arch assessment requires angiography - FALSE, duplex can assess
Pedal arch disease means amputation - FALSE, pedal bypass to patent arch segment is possible
Plantar arch is always from PT only - FALSE, deep plantar from DP contributes

dorsalis_pedis.location: Between first and second metatarsals dorsally
dorsalis_pedis.palpation: Lateral to extensor hallucis longus tendon

arcuate_artery.variants: May be hypoplastic or absent in 20%

posterior_tibial_terminal.location: Behind medial malleolus, under flexor retinaculum

lateral_plantar.course: Crosses sole obliquely to lateral foot then arches medially

arch_connections.deep_plantar_artery: Connects DP to lateral plantar (completes arch)
arch_connections.significance: Allows AT-PT communication at foot level

physical_examination.dp_pulse: Palpate lateral to extensor hallucis longus
physical_examination.doppler: Audible signals if palpable pulse absent

duplex_ultrasound.technique: Linear probe, trace tibials to pedal vessels

angiography.technique: Pedal views, magnified lateral and AP
angiography.consideration: May require selective catheterization for detail

bypass_planning.runoff_assessment: At least one patent arch segment for distal bypass
bypass_planning.target_selection: DP or plantar artery with intact arch connection

wound_healing.complete_arch: Better distribution of perfusion to wound
wound_healing.incomplete_arch: May need to target specific angiosome

endovascular.landing_zone: Patent pedal arch is ultimate landing zone
endovascular.retrograde_access: Can use DP or PT for pedal access
endovascular.recanalization: May need to open arch for adequate runoff

definition.@value: Evaluation of the dorsal and plantar arterial arches of the foot to determine runoff adequacy and wound healing potential.

presentation: Rest pain in arch or forefoot
treatment: Revascularization to most patent arch system

learning_objectives: Describe the dorsal and plantar arterial arches of the foot
Assess pedal arch patency by physical exam and imaging
Explain the significance of arch completeness for revascularization
Apply arch assessment to bypass target selection
clinical_pearls: Complete pedal arch allows single-vessel tibial disease to perfuse entire forefoot
DP absent? Check for retrograde filling from PT through plantar arch
Toe pressures <30 mmHg predict poor healing
Deep plantar artery connects AT/DP to plantar arch - key communication
Pedal bypass targets: DP, lateral plantar, or common plantar
